items.fromString:
So far, we always pushed images with the {{latest}} tag, but in order to be reproducible, attribute problems to commits, and reflect changes in our deployed services automatically, we want to version all our images and reference a concrete version in all our Helm charts.

This ticket is about starting this with our website image.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* The automatically built website image is pushed with a uniquely identifiable version.
* The version contains metadata to identify the commit that was used to build the image.
* The versioning scheme is compliant with Semantic Versioning 2.0.

Right now our Team website is not reachable via DNS. But for this we need an loadbalancer which is currently blocked by waiting of a MR by Central Development ([Add proxy-only subnet for internal ALBs (!4) · Merge Requests · PSI Software SE / Terraform IaC / gcp-2-networking · GitLab|https://gitlab.com/psi-software-se/terraform/gcp-2-networking/-/merge_requests/4])



Acceptance Criteria:

* The Team Website is reachable via DNS
items.toString:
Right now our Team website is not reachable via DNS. But for this we need an loadbalancer which is currently blocked by waiting of a MR by Central Development ([Add proxy-only subnet for internal ALBs (!4) · Merge Requests · PSI Software SE / Terraform IaC / gcp-2-networking · GitLab|https://gitlab.com/psi-software-se/terraform/gcp-2-networking/-/merge_requests/4])

Also our Deployment in ArgoCD try to create the LB but can’t because of missing proxy-only subnets. This is also what the MR is about from above.

After the MR is merged, there may be other stuff to do to get the loadbalancer running. But we don’t know yet. 



Acceptance Criteria:

* The Team Website is reachable via DNS.
* ArgoCD deployment can create LB

items.fromString:
_As a PSIwms customer-project dev, I want to manage my team’s PSIwms servers as Code so I can adapt them as needed on my own._

We want to create a [Crossplane XRD|https://docs.crossplane.io/latest/concepts/composite-resource-definitions/] called {{WmsServerHost}}.

A PSIwms server host is an {{Instance}} that is already prepared to run the PSIwms server:

* Some required system packages are installed.
* Some environment variables are set.

Parameters for CPU, RAM, etc. can come later; a fixed definition of a PSIwms environment is fine for this story.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* The IDP defines one way to declare the WMS server hosts used by a team.
* This way is detailed in the IDP user docs.
* Deploying a {{WmsServerHost}} resource in the {{idp-playground}} results in an {{Instance}} being deployed with the specified preparation to run a PSIwms server on it.
items.toString:
_As a PSIwms customer-project dev, I want to manage my team’s PSIwms servers as Code so I can adapt them as needed on my own._

We want to create a [Crossplane XRD|https://docs.crossplane.io/latest/concepts/composite-resource-definitions/] called {{WmsServerHost}}.

A PSIwms server host is an {{Instance}} that is already prepared to run the PSIwms server:

* Some required system packages are installed.
* Some environment variables are set.

Parameters for CPU, RAM, etc. can come later; a fixed definition of a PSIwms environment is fine for this story.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* A {{WmsServerHost}} CRD is deployed to our cluster.
* It is possible to deploy a {{WmsServerHost}} custom resource from our {{idp-playground}}.

items.fromString:
_As a PSIwms customer-project dev, I want to manage my team’s PSIwms environments as Code so I can adapt them as needed on my own._

Options include:

* A [Crossplane XRD|https://docs.crossplane.io/latest/concepts/composite-resource-definitions/] called something like {{WmsEnvironment}}
* A Helm chart with GCP resources

A PSIwms environment could consist of:

* some VMs, e.g. for {{app}}, {{pos}} and {{web}}
* a VPC connecting those VMs

Parameters for CPU, RAM, etc. can come later; a fixed definition of a PSIwms environment is fine for this story.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* The IDP defines one way to declare the WMS environments used by a team.
* This way is detailed in the IDP user docs.
* Declaring some WMS environments results in those environments being deployed.

This also includes deploying the provider config required for Crossplane to authenticate against Google APIs.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Upon deploying an {{Instance}} resource in our cluster, a VM is provisioned.
* All properties of the {{Instance}} specs are reflected in the VM’s properties, like its name or machine type.
* Removing the {{Instance}} deletes the VM.

items.fromString:
_As a developer, I want some infrastructure deployed for my team._

The provisioned infrastructure should reflect the actual environments currently used by some team in order to get valuable feedback when showing the MVP to that team. For example, WMS environments are usually created from proxmox templates that we can mimic with Terraform/Pulumi configs.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* There is a MR prepared to merge WMS environment provisioning that we can demonstrate on Review.
items.toString:

The provisioned infrastructure should reflect the actual environments currently used by some team in order to get valuable feedback when showing the MVP to that team. For example, WMS environments are usually created from proxmox templates that we can mimic with Terraform/Pulumi configs.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* There is a MR prepared to merge WMS environment provisioning that we can demonstrate on Review.
* The changes shown on Review are easily comprehensible (so the “complex” WMS stuff is encapsulated in a Terraform module).

items.toString:
_As an IDP user, I want to learn about all the IDP services in one place so I can adopt those services on my own._

To improve discoverability of IDP services and to unify their documentation, we want to add a frontend to our IDP, commonly called the Developer Portal.

Backstage is probably the most commonly known portal under a free licence, but there are several more listed here: [https://platformengineering.org/platform-tooling|https://platformengineering.org/platform-tooling|smart-link] 

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Our IDP contains a Developer Portal.
* It has its own DNS name.
* Our readme states the URL of the Developer Portal very prominently.
* Our documentation does not contain information that became obsolete by now having a Developer Portal.

items.toString:
Cloud DNS is not delegated to our GCP projects, but entirely inside the shared project “dev-net-spoke-0”. This might be a GCP limitation, but

# that doesn’t mean that there’s only one way to handle this limitation, and
# we should still point out what problems we expect because of this.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* GKE integration is covered: When deploying an Ingress with a DNS name, the resource record is created in the same project that contains the cluster, not in some other, shared project.
* Shared responsibility and broad access rights are covered: The proposed approach requires granting access to the shared project for many service accounts. Currently, we do not even have read access to that project.
* The report mentions the lack of self-service: We have to wait for a merge of another team in order to create resource records.

items.fromString:
Currently there are problems with deploying ingress for web-clt: 

* The size of the tls key used is too large. 
* Issue with the loadbalancer's healtcheck, created automatically for each service to be exposed. The standard path of this healtcheck is set to root, and some web-clt services return 404, which loadbalancer considers the service to be unhealthy.

*Acceptance criteria:*

* All loadbalancer's healtchecks are correct
* Tls key is set correctly
* Ingresses for web-clt are deployed successfully

items.fromString: k8s cluster is running out of ip adresses for pods
items.toString: k8s cluster is running out of IP addresses for pods

items.fromString:
!image-20241002-105246.png|width=1299,height=673,alt="image-20241002-105246.png"!

Right now range for the ips of pods is {{192.168.1.0/24 }}

So 255 ip adresses. All of them are used (kube-system needs a lot of ips itself)

We have to rearrange this. I would propose following:

{noformat}secondary_ip_range {
  range_name    = "services"
  ip_cidr_range = "192.168.0.0/17" #range: 192.168.0.0 to 192.168.127.255
}

secondary_ip_range {
  range_name    = "pods"
  ip_cidr_range = "192.168.128.0/17" #range: 192.168.128.0 to 192.168.255.255
}{noformat}

This means a range of 32.768 ip adresses.

But for this we have to shutdown the k8s cluster and set it up again. 

That means to deploy stuff again:

* ArgoCD
* Kubeseal
* ?

Acceptance Criteria:

* New Cluster with more available ip adresses is up (/)
* All stuff from before is also deployed.

items.fromString:
We need a way to safely communicate from AB Laboratory to GCP project where PSIwms server is running.

For PoC this access could be granted for each user individually, but for “prod” use case access management have to be able give user/customer possibility control over accessing resources for users or groups based on eg. AD.

This setup should also allow us to add a way to control latency later (add additional latency to the transmission time) eg. route traffic via additional remote server.

Protocols which needs to be passed through.

* https (443)
* tcp - (configurable)
* ssh or access via k8s (ssh or 6443 - k8s API) (to AB Lab only)

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Network access to GCP

* WMS client like PSI Mobile terminal, running on site (AB Lab) is able to log into PSIwms server running on GCP.
* PSIwms server can send requests to NVE service.

customfield_10020.name: DEVOPS Sprint 6
customfield_10020.goal: Run an initial PSIwms/postgres setup in Google Cloud

items.fromString:
We currently have two dockerfiles prepared, separately for oracle and postgres. Ultimately, we want to have one dockerfile, which should be customized in such a way that we can parameterize the build. 



*Acceptance Criteria:*

* There is a Dockerfile in our repo to build an image for PSIwms/oracle and PSIwms/postgres
* There is documentation in our repo on how to build the image.
* Executing on that documentation results in an image on the local machine.
* There is documentation in our repo on how to instantiate a container from that image.
* Executing on that documentation results in a PSIwms container locally that connects to selected database
items.toString:
We currently have two dockerfiles, pipelines, helm charts prepared, separately for oracle and postgres. Ultimately, we want to have one , which should be customized in such a way that we can parameterize the build. 



*Acceptance Criteria:*

* There is a Dockerfile in our repo to build an image for PSIwms/oracle and PSIwms/postgres
* parametrized helm chart that allows us to start oracle or postgres variant of PSIWms
* There is documentation in our repo on how to build the image.
* Executing on that documentation results in an image on the local machine.
* There is documentation in our repo on how to instantiate a container from that image.
* Executing on that documentation results in a PSIwms container locally that connects to selected database

items.fromString: PSIwms image creation refactor to use a single dockerfile for oracle/postgres
items.toString: PSIwms image creation refactor to use a single configuration (dockerfile, helm chart) for oracle/postgres

items.fromString:
We are currently not allowed to expose anything in our VPC via public IP or via public load balancers.

This ticket is about making services in our VPC accessible to explicitly authorized people, by setting up the GCP project in a way where we would be allowed to run deployments containing PSI intellectual property.

We are currently aware of two solutions for this requirement:

* Proper network peering between our dev machine’s local networks. This solution requires approval on group level, and actions from ZIS. We do not expect any of the two in the near future.
* Access via Google’s [Identity Aware Proxies|https://cloud.google.com/iap/docs/concepts-overview] (IAP): when accessing a service secured by an IAP, you are asked to authenticate against Google, and we can control access via IAM policies.

Since IAPs are currently our only option, this ticket is about setting them up for ArgoCD.

A working DNS setup would still require ZIS to take actions, so it’s fine for this ticket to work with temporary replacements if necessary, like /etc/hosts.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* There is documentation on how to access ArgoCD.
* Accessing ArgoCD does not require any tools beyond a plain web browser.
* If you are authenticated as an authorized user, accessing ArgoCD works as before (possibly with some redirects going on before seeing the actual service), with no additional steps required (like kubectl port forwarding).
* If you are not authenticated (try in a new, private browser window), when accessing ArgoCD, you are either asked to authenticate, or just blocked from accessing the service altogether.
* If you are authenticated as an unauthorized user, when accessing ArgoCD, you are either asked to authenticate using another principal, or just blocked from accessing the service altogether.

items.fromString:
Due to recent restrictions, we are forced to make deployments accessible via public IP address, so non-PSI employees are able to reach it, too.

This ticket is about restricting access to explicitly authorized people, by setting up the GCP project in a way where we would be allowed to run deployments containing PSI intellectual property. This will probably be done using Google’s Identity Aware Proxies: when accessing an endpoint secured by them, you are asked to authenticate against Google, and we can control access via IAM policies.

Some technical prerequisites for deploying PSI deployments seamless are out of scope of this ticket, so after this ticket is finished, some technical stuff required to deploy PSI artifacts might still be missing, like a container image registry, are then still missing to do it efficiently, like pipelines or private repositories.

Acceptance Criteria:

* If you are authenticated against Google, accessing the deployments works as before (possibly with some redirects going on before seeing the actual service), with no additional steps required.
* If you are not authenticated (try in a new, private browser window), when accessing that service, you are kindly asked by Google to provide credentials, or just blocked from accessing it altogether.

items.fromString:
We want to make PSIwms/postgres available for deployment in a training environment. In order to keep things simple, we first want to make sure that we can orchestrate it locally. For this, we need two things:

* a PSIwms/postgres image, see [https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-153|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-153|smart-link] 
* a local example Helm chart

We do not require the image to be configurable in any way. One image with a fixed configuration is fine.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* There is a Helm chart in our repo for PSIwms that will deploy a PostgresQL database.
* There is documentation on how to deploy this Helm chart to a k8s cluster.
* Executing on that documentation on a local k8s cluster, e.g. in Rancher, results in a running PSIwms app against a PostgresQL database.
* As soon as deployment is finished, the state of all components of the app is OK.
* There is documentation on how to query the health check API endpoint of PSIwms.
* Executing on that documentation on the deployed PSIwms app results in a proper response from PSIwms server.
items.toString:
We want to make PSIwms/postgres available for deployment in a training environment. In order to keep things simple, we first want to make sure that we can orchestrate it locally. For this, we need two things:

* a PSIwms/postgres image, see [https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-153|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-153|smart-link] 
* a local example Helm chart

This Helm chart could also be used during development by developers to test local changes.

We do not require the image to be configurable in any way. One image with a fixed configuration is fine.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* There is a Helm chart in our repo for PSIwms that will deploy a PostgresQL database.
* There is documentation on how to deploy this Helm chart to a k8s cluster.
* Executing on that documentation on a local k8s cluster, e.g. in Rancher, results in a running PSIwms app against a PostgresQL database.
* As soon as deployment is finished, the state of all components of the app is OK.
* There is documentation on how to query the health check API endpoint of PSIwms.
* Executing on that documentation on the deployed PSIwms app results in a proper response from PSIwms server.

items.fromString:
Being able to deploy code-reviewed revisions of PSIwms via ArgoCD is nice, but not very helpful for development. A developer would rather make changes locally, create all the images required to run PSIwms containing those small changes, and fire up a PSIwms deployment directly.

As a first step, we need a proper way to build those images.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* There is a Dockerfile in our repo for an image containing a PSIwms server that can connect to a PostgresQL database.
* There is documentation in our repo on how to build the image.
* Executing on that documentation results in an image on the local machine.
* There is documentation in our repo on how to instantiate a container from that image.
* Executing on that documentation results in a PSIwms container locally that connects to a PostgresQL database.
items.toString:

* There is documentation in our repo on how to instantiate a container from that image.
* Executing on that documentation results in a PSIwms container locally that connects to a PostgresQL database.
* If this actually results in a PSIwms image specifically for PostgresQL, and something in PSIwms stops us from merging it with the image for Oracle, the documentation contains recommendations on what to change/fix on PSIwms product side in order to have only one image.

We have to set up GCP accounts for all team members, and in order to do so, we are required to finish security training offered by Google themselves. See [here|https://confluence.psi.de/display/OC/GPC+PoC+configuration+and+access+in+phase+1] for instructions.

*Admin accounts:*
||Name||Security training complete
(Steps 1-3)||Account setup complete||
|Denis|(/)|(/)|
|Jan|(x)|(x)|

The course "Managing Security in Google Cloud" has another course, [Networking in Google Cloud: Fundamentals|https://www.cloudskillsboost.google/paths/15/course_templates/35], as prerequisite. If you find that this prerequisite is actually required to follow the Security course, please mention it in the team chat so we can discuss it. We do not want to do a course just for the sake of doing it, but actually learn something from it.

Useful as a very first course: [Google Cloud Fundamentals: Core Infrastructure|https://www.cloudskillsboost.google/paths/20/course_templates/60]

items.toString:
We need to put a load balancer in front of every service that is used in production for high availability reasons. Now, we also have to create load balancers in order to make a service to even make a service accessible at all, since we do not have network peering in place, and we can only reach hosts in our VPC via load balancer. VMs are not allowed to have a public IP address.

*Acceptance Criteria:*
 * A developer can reach GitLab in our Google VPC when connected to PSI networks.

items.fromString: This epic addresses the core challenges of building a foundation of a cohesive, efficient, and adaptive team environment. It focuses on establishing and solidifying the key practices, agreements, and processes that form the foundation of our team's successful collaboration, both within the team and with our broader ecosystem. The tasks within this epic are designed to ensure that our team is aligned, effective, and well-prepared to deliver value in a consistent and sustainable manner while maintaining the flexibility to adapt to changing demands. This includes fostering strong relationships and clear communication channels with all relevant parties. Once these foundational elements are in place, this epic will be closed, marking the completion of this critical phase of our team's development.

items.fromString:
We have to set up GCP accounts for all team members, and in order to do so, we are required to finish security training offered by Google themselves. See [here|https://confluence.psi.de/display/OC/GPC+PoC+configuration+and+access+in+phase+1] for instructions.

*Admin accounts:*
||Name||Security training complete
(Steps 1-3)||Account setup complete||
|Denis|(/)|(/)|
|Jan|(x)|(x)|

The course "Managing Security in Google Cloud" has another course, [Networking in Google Cloud: Fundamentals|https://www.cloudskillsboost.google/paths/15/course_templates/35], as prerequisite. If you find that this prerequisite is actually required to follow the Security course, please mention it in the team chat so we can discuss it. We do not want to do a course just for the sake of doing it, but actually learn something from it.

Useful as a very first course: [Google Cloud Fundamentals: Core Infrastructure|https://www.cloudskillsboost.google/paths/20/course_templates/60]

items.fromString:
This is 2024, duh.

The estimation assumes that ZIS will set up an ACME service for all of PSI to use.

*Acceptance Criteria:*
 * Accessing {{gitlab.log.psi.de}} via http redirects to https on the same domain.
 * Accessing {{gitlab.log.psi.de}} via https prompts for a login if unauthenticated, or shows the GitLab workspace otherwise.
 * Certificate management is fully automated.

This issue is prerequisite for DEVOPS-118
This issue is prerequisite for DEVOPS-117

When upgrading GitLab, we want to destroy, the old compute instance, and create a new one with the new version. For this to work in production, we have to make sure that all data is still there after the upgrade, mostly the projects/repositories. They have to be stored externally on extra storage.

This task might be a no-op, because we might already be there, but we are not entirely sure. In this case, this ticket is just about research.

customfield_10020.name: DEVOPS Sprint 5
customfield_10020.goal: Prepare the team and all their resources for a smooth transition to Google Cloud

items.toString:
The current installation script for GitLab does not have the version as a parameter, so we cannot pin it. The installation is therefore not reproducible, which can cause unexpected problems.

We want to pin the version, and bumping the version should reviewed change in our repository.

customfield_10020.name: DEVOPS Sprint 5
customfield_10020.goal: Prepare the team and all their resources for a smooth transition to Google Cloud

items.toString:
Best case: We have a connection to PSI LDAP, every PSI employee has an account automatically, and we use LDAP groups to manage their roles

This is a long way, though, and we might not even get access to PSI LDAP, so we probably have to go with a local realm for now, creating users directly in GitLab.

customfield_10020.goal: Prepare the team and all their resources for a smooth transition to Google Cloud

items.toString: Create DevContainer for VS Code users

items.fromString:
We need to set up a DevContainer to standardize development environments across the team. This will ensure consistency in dependencies, tools, and configurations, making it easier to maintain the project.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

1. DevContainer Configuration:
 * Create a {{.devcontainer}} directory at the root of the project.
 * Include a {{Dockerfile}} with the necessary environment setup (e.g., OS, languages, libraries, tools).
 * Add a {{devcontainer.json}} file to define the workspace settings, extensions, and configurations.

2. Testing:
 * Verify that the DevContainer works correctly by running the project within the container.
 * Ensure that the devcontainer is usable in VSC and IJ

3. Write documentation as README on how to use the DevContainer

We need to set up a DevContainer to standardize development environments across the team. This will ensure consistency in dependencies, tools, and configurations, making it easier to maintain the project.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

1. DevContainer Configuration:
 * Create a {{.devcontainer}} directory at the root of the project.
 * Include a {{Dockerfile}} with the necessary environment setup (e.g., OS, languages, libraries, tools).
 * Add a {{devcontainer.json}} file to define the workspace settings, extensions, and configurations.

2. Testing:
 * Verify that the DevContainer works correctly by running the project within the container.
 * Ensure that the devcontainer is usable in VSC and IJ

3. Write documentation as README on how to use the DevContainer

items.fromString:
We deployed PSIwms as a Helm chart in IBM Cloud via ArgoCD, and most of it should work out of the box when doing the same using an ArgoCD instance in a GKE. However, the integration of a k8s cluster with other cloud services like DNS and load balancing work slightly different between cloud providers. It will require at least some effort to make it work again.

Moving from one cloud provider to another should only require to adapt the values of a Helm chart deployment. Currently, we have provider-specific values (Ingress controller, storage classes, ...) directly in the templates. Also, a helm chart should not have to contain metadata about where the artifacts are stored.

*Acceptance Criteria:*
 * Make sure that the {{sputests}} that work in IBM Cloud also work in a GKE.
 * The Helm chart templates do not contain any values that are cloud provider specific, or depend on where our artifacts are stored.
 * ... and others, to be done...

items.fromString: This issue is prerequisite for DEVOPS-116

We need connectivity between those networks so we can automate deployments of artifacts in our networks to resources in Google Cloud.

This is probably done by ZIS. In case it is not, we require the following properties for our own solution:

*Acceptance Criteria:*
 * A device outside the PSI or GCP networks cannot reach the GitLab/google instance.
 * Developers who are able to reach Odin can also reach GitLab/google, and the GKE cluster, without changing network settings (proxy, VPN, ...) in between.
